description.standard: Discover new music from artists we think you'll like. Refreshed every Friday.
The songs you love. The more you use Apple Music, the better the mix. Refreshed every Tuesday.
Whether it’s Monday morning or Friday night, get going with this personalized mix of upbeat music.
Handpicked songs to help you relax and unwind. Updated every Sunday.

attributes.name: Wild Wild Son (feat. Sam Martin) [Remixes] - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2019 Armin Audio B.V. under exclusive license to Armada Music B.V.

attributes.name: Can We Pretend (The Remixes) [feat. Cash Cash] - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2019 RCA Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment

attributes.name: Promises (Remixes)
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2018 Sony Music Entertainment UK Limited

description.standard: The only rule for pop in the ‘10s? Trusting your instincts can do wonders for your star power. Take Lady Gaga, who shape-shifted from hard-edged diva to big-voiced balladeer multiple times during the decade, or Ariana Grande, who kept fans guessing with surprise drops and coded lyrics. The 2010s were a wild time on the charts, with pop divas, hip-hop stars, and guitar-strumming crooners all making their own way to the top. Adele belted her way through heartbreak and triumph; Drake got in his feelings over street-sourced beats; Taylor Swift shared her innermost thoughts with millions; and Shawn Mendes made the leap from viral-video star to world-conquering pop icon. Groups hit it big, too, whether they were singing in sweet harmony like the boy banders of One Direction or revamping themselves alongside the times like the soul-poppers in Maroon 5.
description.short: Viral sensations and A-list bops rule the airwaves.

attributes.name: Breaking Me (Remixes)
attributes.copyright: A Virgin Records release; ℗ 2020 Topic, under exclusive license to Universal Music GmbH

attributes.name: New Rules (Remixes) - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2017 Dua Lipa Limited under exclusive license to Warner Music UK Limited

attributes.name: Feel This Moment (Remixes) [feat. Christina Aguilera] - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2013 RCA Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment

attributes.name: Ruin My Life (Remixes) - Single
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2018 Record Company TEN, under exclusive rights to Epic Records US/Sony Music Entertainment Sweden AB

attributes.name: Llama In My Living Room (Remixes) - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2017 House Of Albatraoz under exclusive license to Sony Music Entertainment Sweden AB

attributes.name: Play (Remixes) [feat. Mangoo] - Single
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2019 MER under exclusive license to Liquid State

attributes.name: Midnight (The Remixes) [feat. Liam Payne] - EP
attributes.copyright: 10:22 pm; ℗ 2020 Alefune AB, under exclusive license to UMG Recordings, Inc.

attributes.name: DJ Got Us Fallin' In Love (Remixes) [feat. Pitbull] - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2010 LaFace Records, a unit of Sony Music Entertainment

title.stringForDisplay: If You Like Florence + the Machine

description.standard: When Lana Del Rey released “Video Games” in late 2011, nobody quite knew what to make of her. On the one hand, she seemed like a nostalgia act, the wayward daughter of a Stepford wife tapping into the dark underbelly of suburbia and the American dream. On the other, she seemed utterly contemporary—a detached but self-conscious millennial marking time between selfies. There was something fake, almost alien about her—that blank stare, that perfect hair—but also something wild and passionate, the sound of a young woman trying to vent her desires after being conditioned to hold them in. As her music evolved—from the luxurious club-adjacent sound of 2012’s Paradise to the pastoral grandeur of 2019’s Norman F*****g Rockwell!—her contradictions only got deeper and more interesting. By the end of the decade, she’d transitioned from pop curio to major artist—a shift achieved not so much by changing course but by forging confidently ahead and waiting for the culture to catch up.
description.short: Blurring fantasy and reality with a 21st-century dreamer.

attributes.name: 1000 Forms of Fear
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2014 Monkey Puzzle Records, under exclusive license to RCA Records

editorialNotes.standard: Sia Furler’s sixth album immediately unveils its kinetic potential with the unreined anthem “Chandelier”. 1000 Forms of Fear offers the artist’s most thunderous and frenetic sound to date, employing her powerful voice to punch through layers of tinny electric drums and glitchy synths. Sia teams with The Weeknd and Diplo on “Elastic Heart”, an uptempo electric ballad that uses a dizzying composition and polished harmonies to showcase both Sia’s talent as a songwriter and the album’s skilful production.

description.standard: Andrew Hozier-Byrne's songs draw much of their elemental power from the spiritual heat of gospel music. He conjures dark spirits on bruising and dramatic rock numbers that are sung with total abandon in a high, keening wail, most notably on his 2013 breakthrough hit “Take Me to Church.” And while he's an astute lyricist (“To Be Alone”), it's the power of his soul that produces a sense of romantic drama on “From Eden,” gives monolithic weight to the folky lament “Like Real People Do,” and summons world-crushing passion on “Nina Cried Power.”
description.short: Passionate rock sung with a world-crushing gospel fervor.

description.standard: Theatrical, provocative, and utterly captivating, Lady Gaga is one of the most electrifying artists of the 21st century. She honed her craft as a hitmaker for the likes of Britney and Fergie before commanding the spotlight with the razor-edged dance pop of her 2008 breakthrough, The Fame. In the years since, Gaga's versatility has made her a shape-shifting superstar, equally comfortable singing edgy club hits, emotional pop anthems, and coy jazz standards.
description.short: A career-spanning set from one of the 21st century's most captivating pop stars.

description.standard: Halsey established herself as one of pop's premier young voices in the early ‘10s, when she posted confessional originals and cheeky covers online. Early singles like the spectral, searching “Ghost” and the generational rallying cry “New Americana” combined left-field pop explorations with forthright lyrics, attracting a passionate fanbase. Her cameo on The Chainsmokers' 2016 breakup chronicle “Closer” turned her into pop royalty; she's dug deeper into music's vast territory since, dueting with Fifth Harmony's Lauren Jauregui on the sumptuous synth-pop lament “Strangers” and pairing sunny soul with self-laceration on “Alone.”
description.short: Forthright lyrics give her pop explorations extra power.

description.standard: British singer/songwriter Ellie Goulding partnered with producer Starsmith while still in college, resulting in a unique brand of folk-influenced electro pop that took the UK charts by storm. After a few successful singles overseas, audiences in North America began warming up to Goulding's sweet sound as well, charmed by her ethereal voice and infectious melodies. Soon, Goulding's debut LP Lights became a hit on both sides of the Atlantic. On her 2012 follow-up, Halcyon, she embraced a more introspective sound, which audiences found equally breathtaking.
description.short: Her haunting, angelic voice is only matched by her addictive hooks.

description.standard: Drama is the guiding force behind Of Monsters and Men’s symphonic indie rock—but so is a sense of salvation. First catching ears with stomping sing-along “Little Talks” from their 2011 debut, My Head Is an Animal, the Icelandic quintet storms through heart-pumping crescendos powered by brass, strings, thunderous rhythms, and joyous yelps. Their raw, primal imagery—tongues pulled and wolves ripping through flesh—only adds to the fire. Even as they push their folky roots into heavier rock territory, on glossy anthems like “Alligator,” they still make every beat, strum, and cathartic cry feel utterly profound.
description.short: The Icelandic band’s cathartic indie rock always feels profound.

description.standard: Coldplay articulate the moments and emotions that often seem indefinable—that euphoric high of falling in love, the gut-wrenching pain of falling out of it, the potent buzz of collective hope. It all starts with Chris Martin's sincerity and introspection—he's as likely to reflect and lament as to look outward—and a falsetto that absolutely soars. The band is right alongside him, carrying soft piano-and-guitar rock to heart-racing crescendos, and experimenting, over the years, with orchestral arrangements, moody electronics, and producers like Brian Eno.
description.short: The British rockers articulate moments and emotions that often seem indefinable.

description.standard: Las Vegas quartet The Killers revolutionized indie rock in the mid-‘00s with a synth-led sound that reflected the excess and pathos of their hometown. Fronted by heartthrob Brandon Flowers, the band scored four suitably killer hits with their unashamedly retro debut album, Hot Fuss. A departure into Bruce Springsteen-esque heartland rock on its followup, Sam's Town, proved to be just as commercially rewarding, and by the time that 2008's Day & Age hit the shelves, they had become credible contenders for Coldplay's and U2's stadium-rock crown.
description.short: These arena rockers revel in the glamor and decay of Sin City.

description.standard: Bastille construct songs like modern skyscrapers: Their melodies are epic, but self-contained; their rhythms are sturdy and engineered with precision; their hooks shoot skyward, with gleaming surfaces that can be blindingly beautiful. The London quartet combines arena rock and moody synth-pop, with carefully placed lyrical references—ancient ruins bathed in ash, a hapless noir heroine—that add a bookish edge to their widescreen anthems.
description.short: The low-key Londoners specialize in impeccably crafted synth-pop.

description.standard: Lorde broke through the pop chaos with 2013's “Royals”—a skeletal portrait of suburban-teen class warfare—and her debut, Pure Heroine, put her acerbic voice amidst minimalist beats on tracks like the cooing “Team” and the moodily taunting “Glory and Gore.” She's since worked with pop guru Jack Antonoff to build bigger sonic structures that create opportunities to shake up her persona; she plays a dancefloor-storming diva on the veering “Green Light” and tears open her heart on the ballad “Liability.” Having established herself as a pop titan before turning 18, Lorde seems poised to flourish.
description.short: A pop titan with a bewitching growl.

attributes.name: Dream Your Life Away (Special Edition)
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2014 Atlantic Recording Corporation for the United States and WEA International Inc. for the world outside of the United States excluding Australia and New Zealand.

editorialNotes.standard: On his full-length debut, Australian singer/songwriter Vance Joy offers smartly constructed, sun-dappled roots-pop ballads, delivered in an unaffected tenor. “Mess Is Mine” boasts Lumineers-style handclaps and “Red Eye” features a mournful, mellow twang, while pensive album closer “My Kind of Man” floats on a crystalline falsetto. Rugged and earthy, with an unabashedly tender heart, Dream Your Life Away delivers on the promise of Joy’s ukulele-led 2013 breakthrough single, “Riptide”—and then some.
editorialNotes.short: Timeless roots-pop that’s equal parts earthy and tender.

attributes.name: Handwritten
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2016 Island Records, a division of UMG Recordings, Inc.

attributes.name: glisten - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2018 Republic Records, a division of UMG Recordings, Inc.

attributes.name: Confetti
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2020 Under Exclusive Licence to RCA, a division of Sony Music Entertainment UK Limited

description.standard: When Maroon 5 released their debut, Songs About Jane, in 2002, it was truly novel. Radio was riding out the boy-band explosion, dirgey modern rock was ubiquitous, and hip-hop hadn't quite taken over the mainstream. Fronted by the clean-cut Adam Levine, a suave crooner with a supple voice, the group served up unabashedly tender soft-rock tunes with nods to Stevie Wonder and Michael Jackson. It was a winning formula: They were soon pop mainstays, ramping up the allure of their agile jams with racy lyrics, a shot of electro-funk, overt nods to Prince, and, of course, “Moves Like Jagger.”
description.short: From "This Love" to "Sugar," the very best from Adam Levine and co.

attributes.name: This Town (Remixes) - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2016 Neon Haze Music Ltd, Under Exclusive License To Capitol Records

description.standard: Mixing recent hits with the occasional old favorite, this playlist showcases the lighter side of modern pop—music you can unwind to without drifting away. Lean back, relax, and enjoy. Our editors update these songs regularly. If you like something, add it to your library.
description.short: The mellow side of modern pop.

attributes.name: Demi
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2013 Hollywood Records, Inc.

editorialNotes.standard: Demi Lovato charmed America as a teen TV star, earning generations of self-styled Lovatics, partly because she wears her heart on her sleeve, as displayed on "Heart Attack." With gut-wrenching vocals filled with passion and power, Lovato describes the vulnerability you feel when you truly like someone: "Pain is more trouble than love is worth / I gasp for air / It feels so good / but you know it hurts."

description.standard: There’s an odd misperception that sad is bad—that the only thing to do when we feel blue is cheer up and push through. But there’s a comfort in melancholy that you can’t quite find elsewhere—a feeling of security, of reflection, of bittersweetness and peace. In that spirit, here's a playlist of pop—mixing throwback and older tracks with current stuff—designed to accompany you for solo walks, blue streaks, or quiet moments. We regularly update these selections, so if you hear something you like, add it to your library.
description.short: A pop playlist for embracing your melancholy.

attributes.name: Hold It Together - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2020 Arista Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment

editorialNotes.short: Featuring his breakout hit “If the World Was Ending,” featuring Julia Michaels.

attributes.name: Give You Up (Mark Knight Remix) [Edit] - Single
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2019 Dido under exclusive licence to BMG Rights Management (UK) Limited

description.standard: There's no point denying it: Having your heart broken really, really sucks. Sometimes, during those moments, music is the only thing that can make sense of it all. So we've assembled a set of moving ballads, classic tearjerkers, and recent pop hits to help you through it. Our editors regularly refresh this playlist. If you like a song, add it to your library.
description.short: Let it all out. These songs are here to help.

attributes.name: Speak Now
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2010 Big Machine Records, LLC.

editorialNotes.standard: On Speak Now, Taylor Swift's growth and assertiveness shines through. Each song is drawn from personal experience, from unpredictable relationships (“Mine”) to a carefully crafted response to a very public dressing-down (“Innocent”). Swift exhibits strength and vulnerability — exposing an artist in creative and personal metamorphosis.

title.stringForDisplay: If You Like Lana Del Rey

description.standard: While plenty of R&B stars have chronicled the desperation of heartbreak, few have explored the darker side of love with the intensity of Canadian party monster The Weeknd. He's scored massive hits with undeniably smooth dance-pop anthems and luscious slow jams, whether he's reviving the slick bounce of ‘80s electro-funk on “I Can't Feel My Face” or flipping the club-ready bump of house music into brooding after-dark soul on “Starboy.” That's just one side of singer/songwriter Abel Tesfaye's sound, though. Dropping beats that throb with the sensual menace of classic trip-hop, tracks like “Wicked Games” plunge you into the moment where the ecstasy of a decadent night out teeters on the edge of the regretful morning after. The Weeknd's glittering club bangers will pull you onto the floor, and his steamy between-the-sheets ballads will seduce you. But it's his anguished tales of romantic longing that will haunt your head and your heart.
description.short: The moody R&B superstar explores the agony and ecstasy of love.

attributes.name: We Fall
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2015 Interscope Records

description.standard: Rihanna was introduced to the world by then Def Jam president JAY Z in 2005, and broke through with a demand on behalf of all the gals on the dance floor: Turn the music up. Since then, the Barbados-born pop innovator has been making us beg for more. Starting with 2007's Good Girl Gone Bad, Rihanna has cleverly played with her image, incorporating BDSM allusions and sexual bravado, and expanding her reggae-tinged dance pop to encompass epic EDM, sultry rock, and undulating hip-hop. Even when she's working with larger-than-life foils—Eminem, Drake—Rihanna's still the one making demands.
description.short: Since 2005, this dance pop innovator has been making us beg for more.

attributes.name: Kicker
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2015 Pinetop Records/Hollywood Records, Inc.

editorialNotes.standard: Pop upstart Zella Day delivers a smoldering set of synth-driven pop that showcases the Arizona native’s wide-ranging influences and haunting vocals (reminiscent of Lana Del Rey). While “Ace of Hearts” boasts gilded textures, seismic drums, and a soaring chorus, “Jameson” is a hushed, fingerpicked guitar tune that offers ribbons of starlit pedal steel amidst Day’s gorgeous vocals.
editorialNotes.short: A dreamy, incandescent debut from a towering new pop talent.

attributes.name: I Love You.
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2013 Columbia Records, a Division of Sony Music Entertainment

editorialNotes.standard: The first album from The Neighbourhood, I Love You., is moody, slyly ambitious, instantly gripping, and full of forward momentum. This patchwork of pop, R&B, rock, and hip-hop dares you to imagine what Justin Timberlake might sound like fronting a latter-day Depeche Mode (“Let It Go”), or how trip-hop could have evolved in the 21st century (“Female Robbery”) confidently fusing elements echoing art rock and downtempo hip-hop.

description.standard: Following in the path of her Swedish indie predecessors, Lykke Li uses anything and everything in the studio to craft her bubblegum dance-pop. Her eclectic, beat-heavy sound quickly resonated with fans of the Nordic pop scene, and the success of her debut LP, Youth Novels, launched the singer/songwriter's unique live act into the major festival circuit. She's since matured on record, getting darker on 2011's Wounded Rhymes and dialing up the melancholy for 2014's I Never Learn.
description.short: Get up to speed with this quirky and accessible indie pop.

description.standard: Marina and The Diamonds is the stage name of Marina Diamandis, a Welsh singer/songwriter who makes vibrant, electrified indie pop. Her debut, 2010's The Family Jewels, showcased her theatrical approach to pop songcraft, with songs like "I Am Not a Robot" and "Oh No!" merging big hooks with kitschy synth arrangements. Its followup, Electra Heart, refined this formula, debuting at No. 1 and featuring singles "Primadonna" and "How to Be a Heartbreaker." Much like her music, Diamandis is known for her flamboyant fashion sense and quirky sense of humor.
description.short: This pop peacock delivers flamboyant hooks with a wink and a smile.

description.standard: Tove Lo crafts hard-hitting electro-pop coated in salt and sass. The Swedish singer/songwriter’s provocative tales expose the raw reality of hedonistic habits and painful breakups, starting with her first big single, 2013’s “Habits (Stay High).” Working alongside hit-making producers like Max Martin and The Struts, Tove Lo has since conquered the dance floor—one tear at a time—bringing sadness and self-awareness to the club in the vein of her fellow countrywoman Robyn. All the while, she’s committed to the art of the concept album, breaking down relationship highs and lows into some of the most crude and candid pop to rule the charts.
description.short: The Swedish provocateur coats her dark pop in salt and sass.

attributes.name: Cry Baby (Deluxe Edition)
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2015 Atlantic Recording Corporation for the United States and WEA International Inc. for the world outside of the United States. A Warner Music Group Company

editorialNotes.standard: After a star-making appearance on The Voice, Melanie Martinez delivers Cry Baby, a riveting debut album full of oddball pop that’s both smart and singularly colorful. Lead single “Pity Party” is an explosive update of Lesley Gore’s classic 1963 single “It’s My Party” that echoes the breathy pastiche of Lana Del Rey. On “Dollhouse,” Martinez paints a searing image of a family in turmoil amid ticking clocks, martial drums, and lullaby-like melodies.
editorialNotes.short: The Voice alumna delivers a debut album of smart and singularly colorful pop.

description.standard: Blessed with the extraordinary, multi-octave pipes of an R&B diva, Ariana Grande had already dropped two chart-topping albums by the age of 21. Sure, sometimes she's gotten a boost from friends like Zedd and Iggy Azalea, but Grande's charm really shines on her solo cuts. Check out the soulful ballads and dance-floor bangers that made her a pop phenomenon.
description.short: The pop princess with a massive voice racks up some monster hits.

description.standard: Some people spend their teenage years writing angsty poetry in a locked journal; Billie Eilish put her longing to music. At 14, she made waves online with her haunting breakthrough single “ocean eyes,” which is packed with dreamy romanticism that appeals to her peers and elders alike. Her defiant alto is at once relatable and otherworldly on the moody “when the party’s over” and the thumping “you should see me in a crown,” blending the everyday and the moony in a way that electrifies audiences. Eilish is a decidedly 21st-century pop star whose aesthetic has already blazed a trail for the 2020s.
description.short: It took the ultimate anti-pop star to redefine pop for the 2020s.

description.standard: Spain's Vanesa Martín pours out love-letter confessions in her soft rock, her creativity ignited by the towering romantics of Latin pop and global R&B. The crooner/composer's lovelorn jangle-pop evokes No Te Va Gustar's sentimental steel-string fusions; her poetic drive takes cues from Adele's intensely emotional delivery. And Natalia Lafourcade's love of folk stokes Martín's gitana flair.
description.short: Steel strings and intense emotions excite the Spanish romantic.

description.standard: Sometimes it's hard to figure out if music mimics love or vice versa. Mixing new, upbeat pop with hints of dance and R&B, this playlist captures love's first rush—that little flutter in the pit of your stomach that keeps you just the right kind of off-guard. Whether it's your first night out or you're just hanging at home trying to decide what to text back, let these songs be your guide. Our editors regularly update this playlist. If you like a track, add it to your library.
description.short: Pop songs that capture that first rush.

description.standard: From jazz standards to Motown, these timeless love songs will never go out of style. Our editors regularly update this playlist—if you hear something you like, add it to your library.
description.short: Jazz, classic pop hits, and sentiments that never go out of style.

description.standard: Pop's equivalent of a victory lap, easy listening—a.k.a. "adult contemporary"—essentials don't have a specific style or era in common so much as they share a crucial trait: familiarity. Easy listening's high-profile songs are instantly identifiable classics by blue-chip old (and young) masters like The Beatles, Norah Jones, and Ed Sheeran. And while mellow tracks by Barbra Streisand and Simon & Garfunkel put the crucial "ease" in easy listening, Whitney Houston and Céline Dion amp up the energy with passionate, soaring vocals, proving that adult contemporary isn't only about pop's soft side.
description.short: Pop's mellow masters deliver soothing and familiar feelings.

description.standard: A tearjerking song is often about a sad situation—going through a terrible breakup, for example, or trying to figure out how to live without someone special. But just as many songs flip the emotional script and induce tears of joy; perhaps they describe the ache of loving someone so much that it hurts, or they are simply nostalgic for happier times. Although you might expect tearjerkers to be all slow, downtrodden dirges, these songs actually come in all sonic shapes and sizes: majestic pop ballads, skeletal folk songs, wistful R&B slow jams, and earnest rock songs. No matter the style, the ultimate goal is to make you feel something in your gut, and it can happen in a striking moment—an inimitable Prince guitar solo—or via a brilliantly executed vocal: Whitney Houston’s glassy vibrato; the lonely, keening bray of Bon Iver’s Justin Vernon; Jeff Buckley’s fragile, heartbroken falsetto; or Sinéad O’Connor's full-throated, anguished warble.
description.short: Sad (and not-so-sad) songs say so much.

description.standard: Sam Smith is part of a long line of artists who have used their emotionally wrenching songs as a tool for shared catharsis—although the brokenhearted Amy Winehouse and the grandiose Judy Garland clearly aren't the singer's only muses. Smith has also made forays into dance-commanding divahood that are as inspired by Earth, Wind & Fire's future funk as they are by Lady Gaga's showy synth-pop.
description.short: Catharsis that commands hearts and the dance floor.

attributes.name: To Die For (Remixes) - EP
attributes.copyright: A Capitol Records UK Release; ℗ 2020 Universal Music Operations Limited

attributes.name: Doo-Wops & Hooligans (Deluxe Version)
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2010 Elektra Entertainment Group Inc. for the United States and WEA International Inc. for the world outside of the United States. All Rights Reserved.

editorialNotes.standard: Bruno Mars is a musical renaissance man with his fingers in an amazing number of pies. Mars has an ear for the trends of the moment, but he’s also fluent in old-school methods of songwriting and production. Mars handles the instrumental duties as well as the lead vocals here, bringing a unified feel to this eclectic, high-energy and altogether delightful effort. This Deluxe Version contains two bonus tracks and two videos.
editorialNotes.short: Mars blends of-the-moment trends with old-school methods of songwriting and production.

attributes.name: Love Will Remain - EP
attributes.copyright: A Decca Records Release; ℗ 2020 Universal Music Operations Limited

attributes.name: Chasing Pavements - Single
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2008 XL Recordings Limited.

description.standard: Given the success she's found with her relaxed, breezily melodic pop, it's no wonder singer-songwriter Colbie Caillat grew up on the shores of Malibu. Anchored by the single "Bubbly," her 2007 debut Coco was a huge success, and sophomore effort Breakthrough entered the charts at No. 1. Caillat's profile surged once again in 2011, when "Lucky," her collaboration with Jason Mraz, won the pair a GRAMMY®. In 2014, single "Try," an empowering ballad about being true to oneself, became a viral smash, as well as a testament to Caillat's growth as a songwriter.
description.short: Mellow gold from a genuine California girl.

description.standard: Since the early '00s, the charts have been peppered with singer/songwriters influenced by John Mayer's tender pop-rock. His smooth, relaxed delivery echoes throughout Ed Sheeran's funky, R&B-kissed folk gems and Charlie Puth's endearingly fragile dance pop. Another biggie is James Blunt, whose soul-melting plea “You're Beautiful” is cut from the same cloth as Mayer's most beloved ballads.
description.short: His tender songwriting pervades modern pop, folk, and rock.

attributes.name: Right Through Me - Single
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2019 Golden Love Music

attributes.name: Conversations in the Dark - Single
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2020 John Legend Music, Inc. and Columbia Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment

attributes.name: Yours Truly: The I'm Yours Collection - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2009 Atlantic Recording Corporation for the United States and WEA International Inc. for the world outside of the United States. All Rights Reserved.

description.standard: Love in the 21st century came with a few extra challenges, namely fast technological changes that would transform nearly all methods of wooing, flirting, and hooking up. Fortunately, this gave the biggest pop stars on the planet plenty more to sing about. The first half of the decade saw former teen heartthrobs Christina Aguilera and Justin Timberlake coming of age, navigating fresh love with smooth R&B beats and brilliant falsetto, while making room for openhearted acoustic mavericks, led by Coldplay and John Mayer, to paint their sweetest scenes in spectacular colors. By the second half, Taylor Swift was writing the book on modern love through intimate tales ribboned with exquisite detail, as Rihanna and Beyoncé gave us inspirational anthems that hit straight through pop, hip-hop, and the heart. All the while, understated indie artists like The xx and Death Cab for Cutie helped soundtrack some of TV and film’s most romantic moments.
description.short: Modern romance defined by pop upstarts, R&B divas, and indie darlings.

attributes.name: Return To Love - Single
attributes.copyright: A Decca Records Release; ℗ 2019 Sugar Srl, under exclusive licence to Universal Music Operations Limited

attributes.name: New Adventures in Wonderland
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2019 Independent

title.stringForDisplay: If You Like Andrew McMahon In the Wilderness

attributes.name: TALKING IS HARD
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2014 RCA Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment

attributes.name: LOVETAP!
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2015 RCA Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment

attributes.name: When It Was Now (Deluxe Version)
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2013 Warner Records Inc.

editorialNotes.standard: As indie music has changed and grown, there are frequently discussions about its evolution and commercialization. Bands like Surfer Blood—which employs the deliberately detuned guitars of early-'90s Pavement and Sebadoh—are often called “classic indie.” So where does that leave slickly produced electro-pop acts like Australia’s Atlas Genius? When its shimmering indie pop tune “Trojans” was featured on the Neon Gold site, the three brothers and their keyboard-playing friend landed more than 45,000 downloads. Atlas Genius’ debut album, When It Was Now, still balances the group's glossy production with singer Keith Jeffery's earnest inflections. The opening song, “Electric,” leans more toward neon synth tones and a near-danceable rhythm section that rests comfortably in the crosshairs of The Killers and Kings of Leon (much like the latter band, the brothers Jeffery grew up in a musical family). Conversely, the standout song “Through the Glass” is more organic in its catchiness, with acoustic guitars and handclaps bolstering the radio-friendly melodies. Maybe indie's commercialization is its evolution.

description.standard: When Andrew McMahon made a solo detour in 2004, he did so to find an outlet for material that didn't quite gel with the spiky emo of his main band, Something Corporate. In Jack's Mannequin, he focused on reflective, achingly confessional songs. The outfit's earliest tracks spill over with emotion: “Bruised” frames ambiguous heartache in melancholy chords and sighing melodies. Later tunes, especially those recorded in the wake of McMahon's successful treatment for leukemia, like the wryly anthemic “Hey Hey Hey (We're All Gonna Die),” have a heft that evokes Springsteen and Elton John.
description.short: Andrew McMahon's outlet for achingly confessional songs.

attributes.name: Folk Hop N' Roll (Deluxe)
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2017 Cletus The Van Records

attributes.name: A Bad Girl In Harlem
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2013 RCA Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment

attributes.name: Zac Clark
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2018 Broken Entertainment

description.standard: Cold War Kids' exhilarating indie rock gets its raucous spirit from straight-ahead, hammering percussion mixed with singer Nathan Willett's soulful vocals, which are reminiscent of The Killers' Brandon Flowers. The California quintet's energy level doesn't often dip below 11 on their distinctly rambunctious, keys-heavy tracks, but every once in a while they pull back and slow things down, replacing big, impassioned choruses with subtle rhythms and jangly guitar riffs. These are the their most vital tracks, from rollicking rave-ups to groovy toe-tappers.
description.short: Spirited, rambunctious indie rock with hammering percussion and soulful vocals.

description.standard: Formed in Orange County, California in 1998, Something Corporate fused alt-rock, punk, and emo influences with an emphasis on aggressive piano melodies. Borrowing as much from the tuneful pop-rock of Ben Folds as the snarling crunch of The Get Up Kids, the band released three albums from '00-'03, winning a huge following and plenty of airplay. While frontman Andrew McMahon went on to found Jack's Mannequin, Something Corporate still perform occasionally, and released a greatest hits collection in 2010.
description.short: These piano-pounding emo kids burned hot and bright.

attributes.name: Strange Desire
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2014 RCA Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment

editorialNotes.standard: While he came to prominence as the guitarist for fun., Jack Antonoff formerly fronted the pop-punk upstarts Steel Train and has written songs for the likes of Taylor Swift and Sara Bareilles. He's a pro, in other words, and his craftsmanship shines through on the debut of his new project, Bleachers. Packing more '80s punch than a pair of legwarmers and a can of Tab, Strange Desire looks to acts like Peter Gabriel, Simple Minds, and Duran Duran for inspiration. "Wake Me" has some "Voices Carry" ethereal slow-jam magic to it, and "Rollercoaster" sounds like Blink-182 covering "Dancing in the Dark." Even Yoko Ono shows up to add some angular '80s experimentalism. Yet the smash single "I Want to Get Better" is distinctly of-the-moment, a mash of looped pianos and choral chanting that makes for one of the summer's most unlikely jams.

attributes.name: The Head and the Heart Essentials

description.standard: This Seattle band couldn't have picked a more apt name to suggest their take on Americana—both carefully crafted and brimming with emotion. It's a lot to live up to, but the universal tales of nostalgia and heartache are woven into melodies that feel as familiar as the hearth they yearn for. Three-part harmonies burst through playful piano stompers and cathartic, banjo-and-violin-infused pop with just a touch of mid-period Beatles whimsy. But just as they get the crowd on its feet, they're likely to slip in a poignant acoustic ballad as a reminder to keep the home fires burning.
description.short: Universal tales of nostalgia and heartache that feel as familiar as home.

description.standard: This Southern California quintet paint their bright indie rock with bursts of synth, funk, and soaring pop, and they always have a potent, poignant message. On their 2010 self-titled debut, heart-pumping indie hits "My Body" and "Cough Syrup" are powered by rumbling, propulsive rhythms and ecstatic choruses. Since then, they've flashed some hard-rock muscle, as on the crunchy guitar-heavy romp "It's About Time," while their optimism continues to prevail: Hear their empowering funk-pop tune "Something to Believe In" and the high-flying, love-above-all anthem "Simplify."
description.short: Eclectic, ecstatic indie rock bursting with funk, pop, and love.

attributes.name: Affection - Single
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2015 Cigarettes After Sex

attributes.name: Live from Zurich - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2010 Mosley Music/Interscope Records

description.standard: Leah Dou takes cues from airy electronic music and moody trip-hop—and blends that inspiration with her own C-pop lineage as the daughter of Dou Wei and Faye Wong. This collection distills her music down to its elements: the rawness of rocker Xu Wei; the dreamlike, ambient quality of Moby and Télépopmusik; and FKA twigs' and Lana Del Rey's mix of swooning melodrama and hushed introspection all show their influence.
description.short: The singer/songwriter takes cues from airy electronic music and moody trip-hop.

attributes.name: Beloved - Single
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2019 Mumford & Sons, under exclusive license to Glassnote Entertainment Group LLC

attributes.name: All My Friends - Single
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2020 Byron Langley

attributes.name: Submarine - EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2011 Domino Recording Co Ltd

description.standard: We all need to find our happy place now and then, and these serene, uplifting pop songs are ready to guide you there. Hit pause on life and float along with a set of sweet beats and easygoing melodies. Our editors regularly refresh this playlist. If you like a track, add it to your library.
description.short: Float away with these serene pop tunes.

attributes.name: Blood Harmony
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2019 OYOY

editorialNotes.standard: When Billie Eilish broke onto the alt-pop scene as an angsty outsider-turned-icon—a moment captured in her 2017 Apple Music Up Next documentary—her brother FINNEAS was just a few feet away, having co-written all of the songs from her blockbuster debut WHEN WE ALL FALL ASLEEP, WHERE DO WE GO?. Now, the 22-year-old singer-songwriter is stepping into the spotlight with his own debut EP, Blood Harmony. The title refers to the term used to describe the vocal chemistry of siblings who sing together, and yet the two artists’ styles are remarkably different. Unlike Eilish’s warped electronics and goth-pop sensibility, FINNEAS specializes in upbeat guitar songs: They’re earnest, clean, buoyant, and optimistic, lit by the LA sun. Even the closing track “Die Alone” somehow feels promising and romantic. That both siblings arrived with such distinct and fully formed identities—one anti-pop star, one pop-rock hopeful—is a testament to the strength of their independent creative visions. For a taste, listen to “I Don’t Miss You at All,” a chipper, strummy breakup cut that bundles heartache in hope.
editorialNotes.short: Introducing Billie Eilish’s brother and co-writer FINNEAS.

attributes.name: Some Nights
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2012 Fueled By Ramen LLC for the United States and WEA International Inc. for the world outside of the United States.

attributes.name: Weak Remixes EP
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2017 AJR Productions under exclusive license to BMG Rights Management (US) LLC

attributes.name: She Is - Single
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2007 Epic Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment

description.standard: When Fiona Apple cracked open her pop diaries, she jolted a slew of young artists who wanted to turn their personal histories into songs. Nellie McKay's brassy offerings, Kate Nash's breathless storytelling, and Melanie Martinez's playful arrangements all owe a debt to Apple, while Kanye West's Fiona fandom moved him to work with producer Jon Brion.
description.short: Artists who turned their personal histories into pop stories.

description.standard: When it comes to preserving the integrity of traditional country, few are as passionate or prolific as Alan Jackson. The singer/songwriter from Georgia has become the consistent voice of the hard-working man with a love for small-town living, even while making history as one of the genre's most successful artists. Whether it's dust-kicking romps, heartwarming ballads, comedic ditties, or unifying social commentaries, Jackson carries the torch of Merle Haggard, George Jones, and George Strait with authenticity and liveliness.
description.short: Preserving traditions with passion, authenticity, and liveliness.

description.standard: Bridging the gap between urban and rural life, Luke Bryan crafts some of the most authentic country music out there, with tracks that feel equally at home on the porch or in the stadiums. The son of a peanut farmer, Bryan's Georgia roots run through his relatable sound, while his use of upbeat melodies and huge choruses give him a fresh pop edge. A series of annual Spring Break EPs have turned him into a party favorite, but he's just as adept at the epic tear jerking ballad, making him one of Nashville's most versatile superstars.
description.short: The peanut farmer's son became a superstar.

description.standard: Several country artists bring other genres into the fold to make their sound more unique, yet few people achieve such seamless originality quite like Jason Aldean. Having gotten his start at a Veteran of Foreign Wars show at just 14, Aldean's career has been on a constant rise ever since. In addition to making waves with his far-reaching solo work, the star has also enjoyed collaborative success with the likes of Kelly Clarkson, Ludacris, Luke Bryan, and Eric Church.
description.short: A country man of many talents.

description.standard: With his relatable lyrical themes, everyman persona and public support of the military, it's little surprise that Toby Keith is one of America's best-loved country artists. Capable of tackling both uptempo party jams and emotive political statements, he's remained a hugely popular, and famously outspoken, figure since the early '90s, winning countless awards, selling over 40 million records and racking up a string of number one hits.
description.short: A favorite of the military and the masses.

description.standard: Arguably the wittiest character on the country scene, Brad Paisley is perhaps just as renowned for his comedic outlook on life as he is for his masterful talent. Gaining regional acclaim as a child, the guitar-slinging vocalist's career really took off in the '90s when he moved to Nashville. Since then, he has established himself as both a funnyman and introspective pioneer in the genre, perfectly encapsulating the unpredictability of human emotion.
description.short: A country mastermind with a sense of humor to match.

description.standard: One of country music's most successful trios, Rascal Flatts have amassed a huge fan base since forming in the late '90s, due in no small part to their appearance on Pixar's Cars soundtrack. Renowned for their rich three-part harmonies and down-home charm, the Nashville-based outfit have racked up a string of chart-topping and critically acclaimed albums filled with both heartfelt ballads and driving country pop.
description.short: The Nashville trio is adored by all generations.

description.standard: Nashville's Thomas Rhett is unafraid to test the limits of country music. While “It Goes Like This,” his 2013 breakthrough hit, introduces hip-hop-influenced drums beneath every verse, “Craving You,” a 2017 crossover, combines a New Wave bassline with production tricks straight out of EDM. The unifying factor is Rhett's charm: He's an explorer, but he's also a sweetheart. On “Marry Me” and “Die a Happy Man,” he expresses total gratitude toward the person he loves, the songs' stripped-down arrangements proving that he's just as good when he only has a guitar and his voice.
description.short: Country music that's unafraid to dabble in hip-hop or EDM.

description.standard: Georgia-born Billy Currington is a man of diverse influences, including not only country icons like Waylon Jennings and Willie Nelson, but also R&B giants like Patti LaBelle. That diversity comes through in Currington's music; he may be a mainstream country star but there's a laid-back soulfulness in his delivery. Currington hit it big when his 2010 album, Enjoy Yourself, went gold. With his next couple of albums he racked up a string of No. 1 hits that put his guy-next-door country-boy persona in front of some seriously hook-heavy tunes.
description.short: A Nashville hitmaker with laid-back charm and a soulful style.

description.standard: One of country music's biggest '00s success stories, Dierks Bentley has earned huge critical acclaim through his open embrace of various genres since his emergence in '03. Bringing together elements of blues, rock, folk, and bluegrass, his unique style can be raw and primal in parts, and thoughtfully intimate in others. But whether he's working on his own, or with greats such as Patty Griffin and Kris Kristofferson, his eclectic sound always manages to resonate.
description.short: Straddling several genres, Bentley is a country artist like no other.

description.standard: In the early years of his career, this son of South Carolina was known mostly for the tunes he penned for other country artists. But that shifted in 2009, when Lee Brice released the first single from his debut album. Ever since then, his winning combination of indelible melodies and soulful vocals has made him an artist to be reckoned with. Country fans have come to know him as the kind of performer that puts his all into everything he touches, whether he's churning out a piston-pumping party-starter or crooning a heartbreaking ballad.
description.short: Get to know the country star with a pen as powerful as his pipes.

description.standard: From driving rock classics to heartfelt ballads, Kenny Chesney's back catalog seems to have it all, yet everything still has a signature sound that only he can capture. Known in most circles for his tropical take on country foundations, he brings together various genres and styles effortlessly. As a live performer, every show is an event, with his sold-out stadium tours across the country justifiably earning him multiple Entertainer of the Year awards over the course of his enduring career.
description.short: Country's very own tropical mastermind.

description.standard: Other artists had blended country with hip-hop, pop, and R&B before Florida Georgia Line came along, but Tyler Hubbard and Brian Kelley permanently altered the landscape with their level of flair and became an incredible crossover phenomenon in the process. Together, they weave a blend of earthy and urban that's sassy, soulful, and wickedly catchy all at once. And in between busting out car stereo-cranking anthems like “Cruise” and “Get Your Shine On,” Hubbard and Kelley can downshift to a romantic ballad such as “H.O.L.Y.” and melt your heart with raw emotion.
description.short: A blend of earthy and urban that's sassy, soulful, and wickedly catchy.

description.standard: Country music has always had a tight relationship with the idea of home, and that feeling of kicking back and slowing down when you get there. Mixing rootsy and crossover tunes new and old, this playlist is meant to help you unplug. Our editors regularly refresh these tracks. If you like a song, add it to your library.
description.short: The comfort of home, wherever you may be.

description.standard: Crisp, breezy, but with a little bounce, this playlist captures the lighter side of recent pop—music that keeps moving but stays mellow. Selections vary—a little singer-songwriter, a little R&B, a little acoustic, and a little plugged-in—but the vibe remains consistent: upbeat yet still laidback. Our editors update these tracks regularly, so if you hear something you like, add it to your library.
description.short: Pop that keeps moving but stays mellow.

description.standard: A great song can stand on its own without studio polish or production trickery. Performed by the original artists but presented in a whole new light, these pop hits have been stripped back to their bare, beautiful essence—evocative vocals and absorbing melodies—without losing any of their impact. We update this playlist regularly, so if you like a song, add it to your library.
description.short: Pop hits stripped to their bare, beautiful essentials.

description.standard: A great country song—whether traditional, mainstream, alt, or outlaw—feels like it boils the crazy complexities of real life down to a few short verses. Magic, huh? Powerful, detailed, but concise, the songs here represent country storytelling at its best. Our editors regularly update this playlist. If you like a song, add it to your library.
description.short: Country storytelling at its best.

description.standard: When Paul McCartney laid down the demo for “Yesterday,” he didn't intend for the song to stay so spare—but in the end, the other Beatles couldn't figure out what to play without getting in the way. Point being that even if you're going full-band, there's something about an unplugged arrangement that allows the heart of a song to shine. Spanning old and new, mellow to lively, this playlist showcases the acoustic (OK, mostly acoustic) side of pop: light, direct, and crystalline. Our editors regularly update these selections. If you like a tune, add it to your library.
description.short: The best of pop unplugged, then and now.

description.standard: Timeless, stripped-down tunes by classic rockers and songsmiths.

attributes.name: Camp Katy - EP
attributes.copyright: FP; ℗ 2020 UMG Recordings, Inc.

attributes.name: Live From The Forum MMXVIII
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2020 Eagles Touring Co. II., under license to Rhino Entertainment LLC, a Warner Music Group Company.

attributes.name: Nostalgia - EP
attributes.copyright: FP; ℗ 2020 UMG Recordings, Inc.

attributes.name: À l'aube revenant
attributes.copyright: ℗ 2020 Chandelle Productions, Paris

editorialNotes.short: The troubadour turns to family in an intimate offering.

attributes.name: Sing Up, Sing Out - EP
attributes.copyright: FP; ℗ 2020 UMG Recordings, Inc.

attributes.name: Move Along 15: Live & Acoustic - EP
attributes.copyright: FP; ℗ 2020 UMG Recordings, Inc.

attributes.name: Skeletons
attributes.copyright: An EMI Records Nashville Release; ℗ 2020 UMG Recordings, Inc.

editorialNotes.standard:
It’s thanks to some combination of powerfully persuasive musicianship and sheer stubbornness that Brothers Osborne carved out a place for themselves in the country music landscape during the latter half of the 2010s. TJ Osborne’s guttural, low-slung lead vocals, languid phrasing, and bluesy bends are situated at the intersection of old-school country, R&B, and Southern rock, and never venture into country pop’s presently dominant mode of emulating hip-hop. John Osborne, the older sibling in the duo, serves as co-lead on guitar, putting muscular, incisive playing squarely in the spotlight at a time when beatmaking has much more of a presence in the format than shredding solos. On their first album, 2016’s Pawn Shop, they proved that they're in touch with commercially accessible songwriting sensibilities. By the follow-up, 2018’s Port Saint Joe, they and their bandmates—the rare Nashville outfit to do double duty on stage and in studio—were stretching out.
On their latest, Skeletons, the Osbornes and the rest of their crew, including their longtime producer Jay Joyce, really stoke the dynamic tension between hooks, licks, and grooves and showcase what a deep pocket they have as a band. Partway through "All Night," the sinewy propulsion gives way to the barbed, sneaky precision of John's guitar vamp. During "All the Good Ones Are," funky guitar rhythms graze a meaty, countrified dance-rock backbeat. The title track features a sly, taunting performance from TJ, who reaches cavernous lows and musters a robust attack an octave higher, while the tricky accents of an Appalachian blues-rock guitar riff toy with the timekeeping. The band hurtles from "Muskrat Greene," John’s blistering, chicken-picking instrumental jam, into the down-home show-stopper "Dead Man’s Curve."
editorialNotes.short: On their third LP, the siblings show off their depth and musicianship.
